description:
Aquimarina aquimarini is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It was first isolated from seawater collected near the coast of Jeju Island, South Korea.

Aquimarina aquimarini is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. It is rod-shaped and motile, with gliding motility. The cells typically range in size from 0.4-0.6 μm in width and 1.2-2.5 μm in length.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Aquimarina aquimarini is closely related to other members of the genus Aquimarina, which are commonly found in marine environments. The genus Aquimarina is known for its ability to degrade various polysaccharides and participate in the cycling of organic matter in the ocean.

Aquimarina aquimarini is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature of 25-30°C. It can tolerate a wide range of salt concentrations, with optimal growth occurring in the presence of 2-5% (w/v) NaCl.

This species has been characterized for its potential roles in the marine ecosystem, particularly in the degradation of complex organic compounds and the cycling of nutrients. Further research on Aquimarina aquimarini may provide insights into its ecological function and potential biotechnological applications.
